sect2.title: 64 General Approaches to Identification of Mycoplasma, Ureaplasma, and Obligately Intracellular Bacteria

para.phrase: CÉCILE BÉBÉAR AND J. STEPHEN DUMLER

sect2.para: The bacteria discussed inchapters 65 to 70 differ from bacteria described in other parts of this Manual by several characteristics, including a lack of ideal characterization with the Gram stain method and, except for Mycoplasma and Ureaplasma species and to a limited degree for Coxiella burnetii and Tropheryma whipplei, a requirement for intracellular growth. Thus, the most frequently used tests in clinical microbiology laboratories, Gram staining and culture on artificial media, are often unable to detect these organisms if they are present in clinical samples. Diagnosis of infections caused by these bacteria has traditionally been accomplished by Giemsa and Wright stains of clinical samples, by detection of antibody responses to infection using a variety of serologic tests, or by histopathologic analysis of biopsy samples. Molecular diagnostic tools and enhanced culture methods have significantly improved the ability to detect these agents and to diagnose the diseases they cause. For many of these infections, molecular tools have become standard. The following tables summarize the epidemiology of these infections (Table 1) and the diagnostic tests most often used for detection of the causative bacteria (Table 2).

table.title: TABLE 1 Epidemiology and clinical diseases associated with Anaplasma, Chlamydia, Coxiella, Ehrlichia, Mycoplasma, Orientia, Rickettsia, Tropheryma, and Ureaplasma infections

Cattle, sheep, goats, cats, rabbits, dogs, ticks

table.title: TABLE 2 Diagnostic tests for Anaplasma, Chlamydia, Coxiella, Ehrlichia, Mycoplasma, Orientia, Rickettsia, Tropheryma, and Ureaplasma species

entry.phrase: Giemsa or Wright stain of peripheral blood or buffy coat smears is positive in 25–75% of infected people.
None commercially available; IHC offered at CDC

EDTA-anticoagulated blood collected during the pretreatment acute phase of illness is used for NAATs. Species- and genus-specific tests are described. Current test of choice for diagnosis during active infection.
Not routinely used in clinical practice

IFA is the most frequently used test. In a patient with typical clinical features of human granulocytic anaplasmosis, a ≥4-fold rise in IgG titer confirms infection, and a single peak IgG titer of ≥128 provides supportive evidence. IgG test sensitivity is between 90 and 100% when using paired acute-phase and convalescent-phase samples; specificity is ~95%. IgM testing is not recommended. Cross-reactivity with Ehrlichia chaffeensis occurs.
Organisms may be detected by Giemsa stain or DFA test directed against LPS, but both tests are insensitive.

Available EIAs directed against LPS detect all Chlamydiaceae but are licensed only for C. trachomatis. Antigen tests are much less sensitive than NAATs and are not recommended for diagnostic purposes.
FDA-cleared assays are not currently available, except on multiplex panels.
Widely considered insensitive for diagnosis confirmation. Recovery best if inoculated onto HL cells or Hep-2 cells. Available only through reference laboratories.

MIF test is the test of choice. Diagnosis confirmed by ≥4-fold rise in titer or single samples with IgM titer of ≥16 and/or IgG titer of ≥512. However, the MIF test is often complex to read and is being replaced more and more by EIAs.
Organisms may be detected by Giemsa stain or DFA test directed against LPS, but both tests are insensitive.
Available EIAs directed against LPS detect all Chlamydiaceae but are licensed only for C. trachomatis. Antigen tests are much less sensitive than NAATs and are not recommended for diagnostic purpose.
Requires biosafety level 3 facility and practices; recovered in many different cell cultures including McCoy and HeLa cells
MIF test is most sensitive and specific (test of choice).
Organisms can be detected by DFA test or Giemsa stain. These tests are much less sensitive than NAATs, and their routine use cannot be recommended for diagnostic purposes.

Commercial EIAs for C. trachomatis are considered substandard; they are not recommended for use and are not suitable for screening urine or vaginal swabs. Point-of-care tests are only 62–72% sensitive compared to culture and 33–50% sensitive compared to molecular tests.
FDA-cleared commercial NAATs (PCR, transcription-mediated amplification, strand displacement amplification) are available and are tests of choice for diagnosis of C. trachomatis infections.

Recovered in many different cell cultures, including McCoy and HeLa 229 cells. Test sensitivity is lower than that of molecular tests and dependent on the quality of the submitted specimen. Available only through reference laboratories.

MIF test is most sensitive and specific (test of choice) for neonatal pneumonia and can support clinical diagnostic of lymphogranuloma venereum but is not recommended for other C. trachomatis infections. Rises in titers of ≥4-fold are significant, but rising titers may not be observed with chronic, repeated, or systemic infections. A single IgM titer of ≥32 supports a diagnosis of neonatal pneumonia. However, the MIF test is often complex to read and is being replaced more and more by EIAs.
DFA or IHC may be performed, but these tests are not widely available.

NAATs available through reference laboratories; more sensitive than serology during first 2 weeks; whole blood or leukocyte fractions could have higher concentrations of bacteria, but serum can also be used. Cardiac valve tissue more sensitive than blood for chronic Q fever endocarditis.

Requires biosafety level 3 facility and practices; HHS and USDA select agent. Animal (mouse) inoculation is the most sensitive. May be cultivated in a variety of cell lines, especially HEL, Vero, RK13, THP1, or A549 cells or in embryonated chicken eggs. Axenic culture in ACCM-2 has been developed but is not yet proven for primary isolation.

Most frequently used diagnostic test. Acute Q fever is confirmed by a ≥4-fold rise in IgG titer to phase II antigens. Chronic Q fever is confirmed in a single serum with a ≥512 IgG titer to phase I antigen without risk factors; ≥256 in those with risk factors (aneurysm, vascular prosthesis, congenital heart disease, severe valve dysfunction, or a prosthetic heart valve). A decreasing antibody titer suggests successful therapy. The IFA test that detects both phase I and II IgG is recommended. Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay not recommended for chronic Q fever diagnosis.
Giemsa or Wright stain of peripheral blood or buffy coat smears is positive in 2–38% of infected people.
None commercially available; IHC offered at CDC

EDTA-anticoagulated blood collected during the pretreatment acute phase of illness is used for NAATs. Species- and genus-specific tests are described. Current test of choice for diagnosis during active infection. Sensitivity ranges from 60 to 100%.
Not generally used in clinical practice

IFA is the most frequently used test. In a patient with typical clinical features of human monocytic ehrlichiosis, a ≥4-fold rise in IgG titer confirms infection, and a single peak IgG titer of ≥128 provides supportive evidence. IgG test sensitivity and specificity are believed to be high when using paired acute- and convalescent-phase samples. IgM testing is not recommended. Cross-reactivity with A. phagocytophilum occurs.
Giemsa or Wright stain of peripheral blood or buffy coat smears occasionally reveals bacterial clusters (morulae) in neutrophils of infected people.

EDTA-anticoagulated blood collected during the pretreatment acute phase of illness is used for NAATs. Species- and genus-specific tests are available in some reference and public health laboratories. Current test of choice for diagnosis during active infection. Sensitivity is not currently known but is suspected to be high.
No method of in vitro culture has been developed.
No specific antibody test is available. Antibody tests are based largely on cross-reactivity with E. chaffeensis and alone are not diagnostic.
Giemsa and Wright stains of peripheral blood or buffy coat smears should be examined but have not definitively revealed bacterial clusters in human leukocytes.

EDTA-anticoagulated blood collected during the pretreatment acute phase of illness is used for NAATs. A species-specific test is available in some reference and public health laboratories. Current test of choice for diagnosis during active infection. Sensitivity is not currently known but is suspected to be high.
Not currently used in clinical practice
Currently only available at some public health laboratories; cross-reactivity with E. chaffeensis occurs.
May be detected in genital fluids by use of DNA fluorochrome stains (Hoechst 33258 or acridine orange), but these are not specific and are not recommended for diagnostic purposes.

NAATs are the only practical means for detection of the pathogen. FDA-cleared commercial kits for the detection of M. genitalium alone or in combination with C. trachomatis, Neisseria gonorrhoeae, and/or Trichomonas vaginalis are now available in the U.S. In Europe and various countries, several of these commercial assays can detect M. genitalium and its macrolide resistance-associated mutations, but they are not yet FDA cleared.
Growth conditions are not well established but can require cell culture for long periods. Widely considered insensitive for diagnosis confirmation.
MIF and Western immunoblot methods have been described, although none are commercially available.
May be detected in body fluids by use of DNA fluorochrome stains (Hoechst 33258 or acridine orange), but these are not specific and are not recommended for diagnostic purposes.

NAATs have been developed but because of rapid growth are less useful than culture, except for upper genital and extragenital infections. Commercial assays available in various countries simultaneously detect M. hominis, M. genitalium, Ureaplasma spp., and other STI pathogens. No FDA-cleared tests are available, but RUO commercial NAATs are available in U.S. reference laboratories.

Organisms are isolated from a variety of clinical samples. Dacron or polyester swabs are preferred; wood-shafted cotton swabs should be avoided. Mycoplasmas are extremely labile, and appropriate transport medium should be used. Can be recovered on SP4 broth and agar supplemented with arginine (best overall), on Shepard’s 10B broth, or on A8 agar. Growth occurs within 2–4 days. A variety of kits for detection, quantitation, identification, and antimicrobial susceptibility testing of Ureaplasma spp. and M. hominis from urogenital specimens are available in Europe, and two products (Mycoscreen Plus and Mycofast US; ELITechGroup, Puteaux, France) are now FDA cleared in the United States.
Not commercially available in the U.S. and not recommended for routine use
May be detected in body fluids by use of DNA fluorochrome stains (Hoechst 33258 or acridine orange), but these are not specific and are not recommended for diagnostic purposes.

NAATs are the methods of choice and have higher analytical and clinical sensitivity in most instances than serology and culture. Real-time PCR is highly sensitive in early M. pneumoniae infection. FDA-cleared commercial kits are available for the detection of M. pneumoniae alone or in combination with other respiratory tract pathogens in both the United States and Europe.

Organisms are isolated from a variety of clinical samples. Dacron or polyester swabs are preferred; wood-shafted cotton swabs should be avoided. Mycoplasmas are extremely labile, and appropriate transport medium should be used. Can be recovered on SP4 glucose broth or agar. Growth occurs after 21 days or longer. Widely considered insensitive for diagnosis confirmation.

EIAs are more sensitive and specific than complement fixation and IFA; detection of seroconversion with paired sera is preferred, but detection of IgM antibodies in single sera may be useful. The cold agglutinin test is not recommended for diagnosis of M. pneumoniae infection.
Giemsa and Wright stains of peripheral blood or buffy coat smears should be examined but have not definitively revealed bacterial clusters in human leukocytes.
Available at public health referral laboratories
Not currently used in clinical practice
No specific antibody test is available.
DFA or IHC on skin or other tissues may be performed, but tests are not widely available.

NAATs performed on EDTA- or sodium citrate-anticoagulated blood, buffy coat leukocytes, plasma, or tissue samples obtained during acute phase of illness and from arthropod vectors found on patients; available only through reference laboratories. NAATs provide a higher diagnostic yield (86%) when applied to biopsy specimens and eschar swabs compared to blood (≤81%); specificity is high. Real-time PCR is the preferred diagnostic method for the acute stage of scrub typhus.
Requires biosafety level 3 facility and practices. Not currently used in clinical practice but can be performed only in public health reference laboratories.

When an IFA test is used on patients in a region of endemicity, an admission cutoff IgM IFA titer of ≥3,200 or a >4-fold rise to ≥3,200 in paired convalescent-phase samples is required for diagnosis; lower cutoffs are used for travelers and for populations in which the infection is not endemic. Indirect immunoperoxidase uses light microscopy and is also sensitive and specific. Rapid IgM and IgG diagnostic tests have lower sensitivity than IFA but are best applied to paired samples. The Weil-Felix (Proteus) OX-K febrile agglutinin test is not recommended.
Rickettsia africae, R. conorii, R. parkeri, R. akari, R. felis, and other spotted fever group rickettsiae (see R. rickettsii below)

DFA or IHC on skin biopsy specimen of rash or eschar is sensitive and specific for spotted fever group rickettsiae and available at public health reference laboratories. Antibodies are not commercially available.

NAATs performed on EDTA- or sodium citrate-anticoagulated blood, buffy coat leukocytes, plasma, skin biopsy specimens, or tissue samples obtained during acute phase of illness; available only through reference laboratories. NAATs have poor sensitivity for blood (6–69%) but provide a higher diagnostic yield when applied to biopsy specimens and eschar swabs (48–92%).

Requires biosafety level 3 facility and practices for some species. Heparin-anticoagulated plasma or buffy coat cells or triturated skin biopsy specimens obtained before antirickettsial therapy are inoculated into shell vials seeded with cell lines such as Vero, L-929, HEL, or MRC5. Infected cells are detected by Giemsa, Gimenez, or immunofluorescence staining or PCR after 48–72 h; sensitivity is up to 59%.

IFA is sensitive using R. africae, R. conorii, R. parkeri, and other spotted fever group rickettsial antigens (e.g., R. rickettsii) but is low during the acute phase of illness. A 4-fold increase in titer is generally considered most specific, but single titers of ≥128 for IgG are considered diagnostically significant. IgM titers should not be interpreted alone. Indirect immunoperoxidase is also sensitive and specific. A dot EIA that is modestly less sensitive and specific is available for R. conorii.

NAATs performed on EDTA- or sodium citrate-anticoagulated blood, buffy coat leukocytes, plasma, or tissue samples obtained during acute phase of illness and from arthropod vectors found on patients; available only through reference laboratories. NAATs provide a higher diagnostic yield when applied to biopsy specimens.

Requires biosafety level 3 facility and practices. HHS and USDA select agent. Heparin-anticoagulated blood, plasma, or buffy coat cells are inoculated into shell vials seeded with cell lines such as Vero, L-929, HEL, or MRC-5. Infected cells are detected by Giemsa, Gimenez, or fluorescent-antibody staining or PCR after 48–72 h. Sensitivity is not known.

IFA is sensitive using either R. prowazekii or R. typhi as antigens. A 4-fold increase in titer is generally considered most specific, but single titers of ≥128 for IgG and ≥32 for IgM are considered diagnostically significant. A positive test is not specific for typhus group Rickettsia species owing to broad serologic cross-reactivity.
DFA or IHC on skin biopsy specimen of rash is 70% sensitive and 100% specific. Available at public health reference laboratories. Antibodies are not commercially available.

NAATs performed on EDTA- or sodium citrate-anticoagulated blood, buffy coat leukocytes, plasma, skin biopsy specimens, or tissue samples obtained during acute phase of illness; available only through reference laboratories. NAATs have poor sensitivity for blood (6–69%) but provide a higher diagnostic yield when applied to biopsy specimens (48–92%).

Not generally used in clinical practice. Requires biosafety level 3 facility and practices. Heparin-anticoagulated blood, plasma, or buffy coat cells are inoculated into shell vials seeded with cell lines such as Vero, L-929, HEL, or MRC-5. Infected cells are detected by Giemsa, Gimenez, or fluorescent-antibody staining or PCR after 48–72 h. Sensitivity is not known.

IFA is sensitive using R. rickettsii or other spotted fever group rickettsial antigens but is low during the acute phase of illness. A 4-fold increase in titer is generally considered most specific, but single titers of ≥128 for IgG and ≥32 for IgM are considered diagnostically significant. IgM titers should not be interpreted alone. A positive serologic test is not specific for R. rickettsii infection owing to broad serologic cross-reactivity among spotted fever group Rickettsia species. EIAs are commercially available but not FDA cleared and not recommended.
DFA or IHC on a skin biopsy specimen of a rash is sensitive and specific. Available at public health reference laboratories. Antibodies are not commercially available.

NAATs performed on EDTA- or sodium citrate-anticoagulated blood, buffy coat leukocytes, plasma, or tissue samples obtained during acute phase of illness; available only through reference laboratories. NAATs have poor sensitivity for blood but provide a higher diagnostic yield when applied to biopsy specimens.

Requires biosafety level 3 facility and practices. Heparin-anticoagulated blood, plasma, or buffy coat cells are inoculated into shell vials seeded with cell lines such as Vero, L-929, HEL, or MRC-5. Infected cells are detected by Giemsa, Gimenez, or fluorescent-antibody staining or PCR after 48–72 h. Sensitivity is not known.

IFA is sensitive using either R. prowazekii or R. typhi as the antigen. A 4-fold increase in titer is generally considered most specific, but single titers of ≥128 for IgG and ≥32 for IgM are considered diagnostically significant. Indirect immunoperoxidase is also sensitive and specific. A dot EIA that is modestly less sensitive and more specific than IFA is available for R. typhi. Cross-reactivity with spotted fever group Rickettsia species can occur. EIAs are commercially available, but none are FDA cleared or currently recommended.
Tissue biopsy with periodic acid-Schiff stain, IHC, or fluorescence in situ hybridization; electron microscopy

NAATs are currently the preferred method for specific diagnosis; performed on fresh, frozen, or paraffin-embedded small intestinal biopsy specimens, cardiac valve tissues, lymph nodes, liver, synovium, central nervous system samples, skin, saliva, and stools. Can be used in blood, but a negative result does not rule out infection. Available through reference laboratories.
Isolation requires long-term (>30 days) culture and is currently available in only a few research and reference/public health laboratories around the world.
May be detected in body fluids using DNA fluorochrome stains (Hoechst 33258 or acridine orange), but these are not specific and not recommended for diagnostic purposes.

NAATs have been developed but are less useful than culture, except for extragenital infections. Commercial assays available in various countries simultaneously detect M. hominis, M. genitalium, Ureaplasma spp., and other STI pathogens. No FDA-cleared tests are available, but RUO commercial NAATs are available in U.S. reference laboratories.

Organisms are isolated from a variety of clinical samples. Dacron or polyester swabs are preferred; wood-shafted cotton swabs should be avoided. Ureaplasmas are extremely labile, and appropriate transport medium should be used. Can be recovered on Shepard’s 10B urea broth and A8 agar. Growth occurs within 2–4 days. A variety of kits for detection, quantitation, identification, and antimicrobial susceptibility testing of Ureaplasma spp. and M. hominis from urogenital specimens are available in Europe, and two products are now FDA cleared in the United States.
